This is a modified protocol from Kirchweger et al., 19945.

1. Transform Lbpro or Lbpro* plasmid into BL21(DE3) pLysE or pLysS E. coli cells using standard methods.
Plate the cells onto a LB

Critical Step: Lbpro* expression in E. coli strains other than pLysE or pLysS may lead to premature lysis and therefore reduced yields.

Supplement LB medium with 100 µg/ml Ampicillin and 30 µg/ml Chloramphenicol).

4.

6.

Cool the culture for 30 min at 18 °C while shaking at 150 r.p.m.

7.

Induce expression of Lbpro* with 0.4 mM IPTG (final concentration).

8.

Incubate the culture for 16-20 h at 18 °C while shaking at 110 r.p.m.

9.

Harvest cells by centrifugation at 5,000 x g for 15 min at 4 °C.

10.
Pellet in 30 mL Buffer A and

Proceed onto the cell lysis procedure.

2.

3.

3.

4.

Precipitate proteins from the supernatant, including Lbpro*, by adding the 100% saturated ammonium sulfate solution as before to a final concentration of 60%.

6.

7.

Centrifuge solution at 50,000 x g for 30 min at 4 °C.

8.

Pellet in Buffer A (8 mL of Buffer A per 1 L of cell culture) on a roller mixer.

Generation of substrates for Ub-clipping

Ub-clipping can be performed on any ubiquitinated substrate or sample.
Here we describe the preparation and Lb<sup>pro</sup>* digestion of three different ubiquitin samples.
This includes: I) total ubiquitin from whole cell lysate, II) purified ubiquitin chains from cells, and III) isolated mitochondria.

Together, these protocols will not only facilitate the analysis of these substrates, but also serve as a reference point for Ub-clipping analysis of other ubiquitinated proteins.﻿

I.

Culture cells in one 15 cm petri dish containing Dulbecco’s Modified Eagle’s Medium (DMEM) supplemented with 10% (v/v) fetal calf serum and PenStrep (Penicillin and Streptomycin).

2.
Place petri dish on ice and

Wash cells 2x with 10 mL of ice-cold PBS.

5.

Add 500 µL PBS to the petri dish.

7.

Transfer to a pre-chilled 1.5 mL tube.

8.

Centrifuge at 300 x g for 2 min at 4 °C.

9.

Proceed with the protein extraction procedure described below.

(B)

Pellet in 300 µL of freshly prepared extraction buffer.

2.
Sonicate the sample using a microtip (recommended sonication settings: 10 sec burst, 10 sec off, amplitude 5-10 W for 1 min).

Note: cells can also be lysed by passing the sample through a 26.5 Gauge needle.

3.

Incubate sample on ice for 1 min.

4.

Centrifuge cell lysate at 21,000 x g for 10 min at 4 °C.

6.

Add fresh DTT to a final concentration of 10 mM.

7.

Determine the protein concentration with a Bradford assay.

8.

Reduce the final concentration of urea to 1 M, a concentration in which Lbpro* is active.

9.

Proceed with Lbpro* digestion and purification of total ubiquitin.

(C) Lbpro* digestion and purification of ubiquitin

1.
Add Lb<sup>pro</sup>*<sup> </sup>to the diluted cell lysate and
Overnight digestion with 10 μM Lb<sup>pro</sup>* is sufficient to collapse the ubiquitin smear (<strong>Fig.

For WT Lbpro, we recommend using a concentration higher than 10 μM during digestion.

2.

Add Lbpro-treated sample to a pre-soaked dialysis tubing or cassette (3.5K MWCO).

3.

Dialyze sample in cold Milli-Q water overnight at 4 °C with gentle stirring.

4.

Centrifuge sample at 21,000 x g for 10 min at 4 °C.

6.
Run the supernatant on a Superdex 75 Increase 3.2/300 gel filtration column using an ÄKTA Micro system. Note: We recommend connecting a

This will help minimize unwanted damage to the column.

8.

Identify ubiquitin-containing fractions with anti-ubiquitin Western blots.

9.
Concentrate using an Amicon Ultra-15 centrifugal

Note: Minimize contamination of unwanted proteins from the early fractions containing the void elution, as these proteins will interfere with downstream mass spectrometry analysis.

Purification of ubiquitin chains and digestion with Lbpro*

(A) TUBE pull-down and digestion

Note:

The TUBE pull-down procedure is a modified protocol from Hjerpe et al., 20094.

1.

Harvest one 10 cm petri dish of cells as described above.

2.

Suspend the cell pellets in 300 µL TUBE lysis buffer.

3.

Supplement the lysis buffer with 100 µg of GST 4x ubiquilin 1 TUBE4.

4.

Clear lysate by centrifugation at 21,000 x g for 10 min at 4 °C.

6.

Incubate sample with 25 µL pre-washed Glutathione Sepharose 4B resin

on a rotating wheel for 2 h at 4 °C.

7.
Centrifuge sample at 300 x g for 2 min at 4 °C and

Wash beads with 500 µL ice-cold PBS + 0.1% Tween20 (v/v).

9.
Centrifuge sample at 300 x g for 2 min at 4 °C and
Incubate TUBE-bound ubiquitin chains with 100 µL of 10 µM Lb<sup>pro</sup>* in TUBE digestion buffer for 16 h at 37°C.

This is an on-bead cleavage assay, where Lbpro* clips and releases ubiquitin into supernatant.

13.

Centrifuge sample at 300 x g for 2 min at 4 °C.

14.
Transfer supernatant to a fresh tube and
Add perchloric acid to the ubiquitin sample to a final concentration of 0.5% (v/v),

Incubate sample for 10 min on ice.

3.
Centrifuge sample at 21,000 x g for 10 min at 4 °C.
This step retains the ubiquitin species in the supernatant.

Place the ubiquitin-containing supernatant in a pre-soaked Slide-A-Lyzer MINI 3.5 K (MWCO).

5.

Tris (pH 7.4) for 4 h at 4 °C with gentle stirring.

6.

Dialyze sample in cold Milli-Q water overnight at 4 °C with gentle stirring.

7.

Isolation of damaged mitochondria and digestion with Lbpro*

(A)

Culture cells in two 15 cm petri dishes containing Dulbecco’s Modified Eagle’s Medium (DMEM) supplemented with 10% (v/v) fetal calf serum and PenStrep (Penicillin and Streptomycin).

2.
Treat cells with DMEM medium containing OA (10 μM oligomycin and 4 μM Antimycin A) and

Incubate for 2 h back in the 37 °C incubator.

4.
Place petri dish on ice and
Wash cells 2x with 10 mL of ice-cold PBS.<strong>

Note: PBS can be supplemented with 200 mM chloroacetamide to further inhibit deubiquitinase activity.

6.

Transfer to a pre-chilled 1.5 mL tube.

7.

Centrifuge at 1,000 x g for 5 min at 4 °C.

8.
Wash the cells with PBS and

Proceed to the purification of mitochondria.

B) Purification of mitochondria

Note:
This protocol was adapted from Lazarou et al., 2007 <sup>6</sup>.

All steps should be performed on ice or at 4 °C.﻿

1.

Suspend cell pellets in 2.5-5 mL of mitochondrial isolation buffer containing 1x cOmplete Protease Inhibitor Cocktail and 1x PhosSTOP Phosphatase Inhibitor Cocktail.

2.
Transfer resuspended cells to a 5 mL dounce homogeniser and homogenise with 25-30 strokes with a drill-fitted pestle.

Ensure the cells are properly disrupted without damage to mitochondria, the number of strokes may be varied depending on the torque of the drill.

4.

Transfer the sample to a 50 mL tube.

5.

Centrifuge at 1,000 x g for 5 min at 4 °C.

6.

Split the supernatant across several 1.5 mL tubes.

7.

Centrifuge at 10,000 x g for 10 min at 4 °C.

8.
Note: Steps 1-3 can be repeated with the 1,000 x g

Pellet to liberate more mitochondria from unbroken cells.

9.

Pool the 10,000 x g pellets in 1 mL of mitochondrial isolation buffer.

10.
Centrifuge at 1,000 x g for 5 min at 4 °C.

Suspend the mitochondria will cause them to be lost at this step.

11.

Transfer the supernatant to a fresh 1.5 mL tube.

12.

Centrifuge at 10,000 x g for 10 min at 4 °C.

13.

Pellet in 1 mL mitochondrial isolation buffer excluding the inhibitors.

14.

Centrifuge at 10,000 x g for 10 min at 4 °C.

15.

Pellet in 1 mL of sucrose storage buffer.

17.
Determine the protein concentration using a BCA assay.

Samples can be stored at -80 °C until needed.

(C)

Sodium carbonate extraction and Lbpro* digestion of purified mitochondria

Note:

The sodium carbonate extraction procedure was adapted from Fujiki et al., 1982a & 1982b7,8

1.

Thaw the isolated mitochondria on ice.

2﻿. Aliquot the desired amount of protein in a 1.5 mL tube.

The amount of mitochondria can range between 0.2-1 mg per sample and will depend on the downstream application as well as density of ubiquitination.

3.
Extract the soluble and peripheral membrane proteins by resuspending the

Pellet in fresh sodium carbonate solution at a ratio of 1 μL per μg mitochondria.

4.

Incubate the sample for 30-45 min on ice with occasional vortexing.

5.

Centrifuge at 21,000 x g for 30 min at 4 °C.

6.

The degree of extraction depends on the pH of the Na2CO3, so this should be measured and kept constant across experiments.

7.

Pellet in mitochondria Lbpro digestion buffer at a ratio of 1 μL per 10 μg mitochondria.

8.

Add an equal volume of mitochondria Lbpro digestion buffer containing 20 μM Lbpro*.

9.

Reduce the catalytic cysteine of Lbpro*, DTT inhibits a mitochondrial carboxypeptidase that cleaves Arg74 of ubiquitin after Lbpro* cleavage.

10.

Centrifuge sample at 21,000 x g for 30 min at 4 °C.

11.
Protein can be immediately flash-frozen in liquid nitrogen or aliquoted and lyophilized.

Store sample at -80 °C.

Mass spectrometry & Ub-clipping analysis

Mass spectrometry analysis will largely depend on the available equipment.
As a result, in this section of the protocol we have minimized instrument-specific details and provided general guidelines for analysis and data processing of samples.
For specific details on reagents and instrumentation, please

See the method section of our paper.

(A)

The resuspension volume will depend on the sample and sensitivity of the mass spectrometer.

2.
Desalt your sample using C<sub>4</sub> reverse phase media before mass spectrometry analysis.

This can be performed before or during HPLC runs.

3.

Separate ubiquitin species with an analytical column packed with C4 reverse phase media.

4.
Standard acetonitrile gradients can be used to

Elute ubiquitin from the analytical column.

5.

We recommend performing mass analysis at the highest mass resolution setting possible.

(B)
The analysis of ubiquitin modifications from mass spectrometry data files can be performed by peak integration or spectra deconvolution.
Note: In many cases both approaches yield comparable results.

However, spectra deconvolution is preferred when quantifying both phosphorylation and ubiquitination sites.

2.
For peak integration, quantitation should be performed on the ubiquitin species with the highest intensity (e.g. ubiquitin with a charge state of 12) and the nominal mass.
Export the area under the curve for each species and
For spectra deconvolution, all spectra corresponding to ubiquitin should be averaged and deconvoluted.
Export the intensities of each ubiquitin species and
